title: Analysis of the 2025 WNBA Season
text:
Motivation
In 2019, women made up 44% of all sports participants, but received less than 5% of sports media coverage and less than 1% of total sports sponsorship dollars (Togethxr). In recent years, however, women’s sports have experienced a rapid rise in popularity. This has coincided with the growth of the Women’s National Basketball Association (WNBA). The 2025 season set new records for both attendance and viewership. The league, which currently consists of 13 teams, has announced that it plans to expand to 18 teams by 2030. The growth of the WNBA has also created new opportunities for women off the court with more women occupying positions as media commentators, analysts, coaches, and executives. However, there is still work to be done. Although the WNBA is receiving more attention, athletes aren’t being compensated at an equivalent rate. Players, uniting under slogans like “Pay Us What You Owe Us,” are demanding a larger cut of the league’s increased media revenue. As student-athletes, we were interested in exploring the 2025 WNBA season, analyzing performance at the team and individual levels and how it relates to player earnings and popularity.
crumbs: 1  Performance Analysis of the 2025 WNBA Season

text: Passionate fans of the Golden State Valkyries whose inaugural season was 2025 (Beth LaBerge/KQED).

title: Analysis of the 2025 WNBA Season
text:
Research Question
Our primary research question is: what factors were associated with individual and team success throughout the 2025 WNBA season?
In this analysis, we present insightful ways of measuring and visualizing team and player performance. We incorporate machine learning for the purposes of determining the best predictors of game outcome and validating our summaries of player performance. We also explore the relationships between player performance and between salary and social media presence.
crumbs: 1  Performance Analysis of the 2025 WNBA Season

title: Analysis of the 2025 WNBA Season
text:
Background
The WNBA is the professional women’s basketball league in the United States. There are 13 teams in the WNBA, and there are 12 rostered players (players that are actively playing) on each team. The entire league is split into two conferences, the Eastern and Western Conferences. Every team plays 44 games in a regular season, most games against teams in their conference but some outside. After the regular season ends, the best teams move onto an elimination tournament called the playoffs. The playoffs include the top 8 teams in either conference, based on win-loss record. These teams compete in a series of games where losing teams are gradually eliminated until only one remains. The final winner is crowned the WNBA champion.
Because our project analyzes team and individual performance, it is important to understand the common statistics that help measure performance:

Points per game (PPG): total number of points scored per game
Shots: total number of shots taken, including missed shots
Assists: passes made that directly led to a point scored
Blocks: blocking and opponents shot to prevent a point
Steals: taking the ball away from the opponent before they can take a shot
Rebounds: gaining possession of the ball after a missed shot (offensive or defensive)
Turnovers: the opposite of steals; losing the ball to the opponent before they take a shot
Record: this is the total amount of wins and losses that a team accumulates
crumbs: 1  Performance Analysis of the 2025 WNBA Season

title: Analysis of the 2025 WNBA Season
text:
Data
Wehoop is an R package for analyzing women’s college and professional basketball data. It is a scraping and aggregating interface for ESPN’s women’s college basketball and WNBA statistics developed by Saiem Gilani and Geoff Hutchinson. In this analysis, we use wnba play-by-play, team box score, and player box score datasets from 2025. The play-by-play dataset (121,342 x 62) contains every play from every game. It has text explaining the type of play (layup, rebound, foul, substitution, free throw, etc.) and players involved. It also has timestamps, player coordinates, and basic game information. The team box score dataset (624 x 57) has information about team performance for every game, including total shots attempted and made, fouls, rebounds, turnovers, and more. It also contains useful information for creating visualizations such as team colors and logos. The player box score dataset (7,140 x 57) contains similar in-game statistics as the team box score dataset but broken down by individual. It also has basic player information including position and whether or not the player is a starter. Across all datasets, very little cleaning was required apart from the removal of the All Star game.


Code
# load necessary packages
library(wehoop)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)
library(glmnet)
library(tidymodels)
tidymodels_prefer()
library(robotstxt)
library(rvest)
library(factoextra)
library(reshape2)
library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)
library(plotly)

# load wehoop data
wnba_pbp <- wehoop::load_wnba_pbp()
wnba_team_box <- wehoop::load_wnba_team_box()
wnba_player_box <- wehoop::load_wnba_player_box()


Salary information for each player was scraped from herhoopstats.com and assembled into a dataframe (255 x 5). The information was independently sourced by Richard Cohen. To retrieve the data, we created a function that iterates through each team’s 2025 Salary Cap Sheet page and extracts the player name, team name, salary value, and contract type. The data had to be cleaned so that it was fit for analysis and could be joined with other datasets. Missing values were populated with NA and categories were collapsed and recoded. Additionally, some players had multiple contracts with the same or different teams, which was addressed on a case by case basis in later analysis.


Code
# scrape herhoopstats.com for salary data
start_url <- "https://herhoopstats.com/salary-cap-sheet/wnba/team/2025/"
team_urls <- c(
  "atlanta-dream-11eaecc7-356c-1364-b611-2362f5011b0b",    
  "chicago-sky-11eaecc7-355f-1c4a-b611-2362f5011b0b",     
  "connecticut-sun-11eaecc7-3562-4a0a-b611-2362f5011b0b",     
  "dallas-wings-11eaecc7-3583-13fc-b611-2362f5011b0b",     
  "golden-state-valkyries-11efb2ba-e2c6-f520-8806-9a93b15b3fec", 
  "indiana-fever-11eaecc7-3565-c004-b611-2362f5011b0b",
  "las-vegas-aces-11eaecc7-3575-e2fe-b611-2362f5011b0b",
  "los-angeles-sparks-11eaecc7-3579-2ce8-b611-2362f5011b0b",
  "minnesota-lynx-11eaecc7-357c-772c-b611-2362f5011b0b",
  "new-york-liberty-11eaecc7-356f-5524-b611-2362f5011b0b",
  "phoenix-mercury-11eaecc7-357f-c1ca-b611-2362f5011b0b",
  "seattle-storm-11eaecc7-3572-876c-b611-2362f5011b0b",
  "washington-mystics-11eaecc7-3568-d154-b611-2362f5011b0b"
)
full_urls <- str_c(start_url, team_urls, "/")

salary_info <- function(url) {
  Sys.sleep(1)
  webpage <- read_html(url)

  team <- webpage %>%
    html_element("h1.salary_title") %>%
    html_text(trim = TRUE)
  
  rows <- webpage %>%
    html_elements("tbody tr")

  map_df(rows, function(row) {

    player <- row %>%
      html_element("td.salary_player_name a") %>%
      html_text(trim = TRUE)

    salary_cell <- row %>%
      html_elements("td.salary_cap_hit") %>%
      .[1]

    salary <- salary_cell %>%
      html_attr("sorttable_customkey") %>%
      as.numeric()

    contract_type <- salary_cell %>%
      html_attr("title") %>%
      na_if("")

    tibble(
      name = player,
      team = team,
      salary = salary,
      contract = contract_type
    )
  })
}

all_pages <- purrr::map(full_urls, salary_info)
salary_df <- bind_rows(all_pages)

# clean up salary dataframe
salary_df$salary[salary_df$salary == 0] <- NA
salary_df <- salary_df %>%
  mutate(contract = str_extract(contract, "^[^<]*")) %>%
  mutate(team = str_extract(team, "(?<=2025 ).*")) %>%
  mutate(team = str_extract(team, ".*(?= Salary Cap Sheet)")) %>%
  mutate(team_name = case_when(
    team == "Atlanta Dream" ~ "Dream",
    team == "Chicago Sky" ~ "Sky",
    team == "Connecticut Sun" ~ "Sun",
    team == "Dallas Wings" ~ "Wings", 
    team == "Golden State Valkyries" ~ "Valkyries",
    team == "Indiana Fever" ~ "Fever",
    team == "Las Vegas Aces" ~ "Aces",
    team == "Los Angeles Sparks" ~ "Sparks",
    team == "Minnesota Lynx" ~ "Lynx",
    team == "New York Liberty" ~ "Liberty",
    team == "Phoenix Mercury" ~ "Mercury",
    team == "Seattle Storm" ~ "Storm",
    team == "Washington Mystics" ~ "Mystics")) %>%
  mutate(contract = 
    fct_collapse(contract,
      "Protected Veteran" = c("Protected Veteran"),
      "Unprotected" = c("Unprotected"),
      "7-Day Contract" = c("Complete 7-Day Contract"),
      "Hardship Contract" = c("Complete Hardship Contract", "Active Hardship Contract"), 
      "Waived" = c("Waived", "Waived Protected Veteran"),
      "Protected Rookie Scale" = c("Protected Rookie Scale"),
      "Buyout" = c("Buyout")
    )) %>% 
  mutate(across(where(is.numeric), ~ ifelse(is.nan(.), NA, .)))


Social media popularity was measured by considering the number of Instagram followers each player has. We scraped revoltv.com to create a 10 by 2 dataframe of the top 10 most followed players and their follower count. The data had to be cleaned to extract the players’ names and total number of followers. For players not in the top 10 most followed list, we manually added their follower count by looking up their accounts on the app.


Code
# social media data
url <- "https://www.revolt.tv/article/wnba-players-with-the-most-instagram-followers"

page <- read_html(url)

# extract elements
headers <- page %>%
  html_elements("h2 strong") %>%
  html_text2

# clean data frame
most_followers <- headers %>%
  str_remove("^\\d+\\.\\s*") %>%
  str_match("^(.*?)\\s*\\((.*)\\)$") %>% 
  as_tibble() %>%
  select(V2, V3) %>%
  mutate(V3 = V3 %>%                  
           str_remove("over\\s*") %>%           
           str_replace(" million", "e6") %>%    
           as.numeric()) %>%
filter(V2 != "Candace Parker") %>%
  arrange(desc(V3)) %>%
  slice(1:10) 

colnames(most_followers) <- c("athlete_display_name", "follower_count")

# create variable for followers in millions
most_followers <- most_followers %>%
  mutate(followers_millions = follower_count/1000000)
crumbs: 1  Performance Analysis of the 2025 WNBA Season

title: Analysis of the 2025 WNBA Season
text:
Analysis and Insights

Team Performance
We began our analysis by looking into team performance, identifying the strongest and weakest teams in the league.

Season records
As a starting point, we made a visualization of the progression of each team’s record, represented by cumulative wins, over the course of the season. This provides insight into how team’s performed relative to each other at each point in the season, information that cannot be derived from their records alone. A grey dashed line was added to mark the end of the regular season and beginning of the playoffs. The lines for each team end at varying points, depending on if they made the playoffs and when they were eliminated.


Code
# determine records for each team
wnba_team_records <- wnba_team_box %>%
  # remove all star teams
  filter(team_name != "TEAM CLARK", team_name != "TEAM COLLIER") %>% 
  mutate(
    win = ifelse(team_winner == TRUE, 1, 0),
    loss = ifelse(team_winner == FALSE, 1, 0)
  ) %>%
  group_by(team_name) %>%
  arrange(team_name, game_date) %>% 
  mutate(
    cumulative_wins = cumsum(win),
    cumulative_losses = cumsum(loss),
    record = paste0(cumulative_wins, "-", cumulative_losses),
    win_pct = cumulative_wins/(cumulative_wins + cumulative_losses)
  ) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate(team_color = paste0("#", team_color))

# team color hex codes
team_colors <- wnba_team_box %>%
  distinct(team_name, team_color) %>%
  mutate(team_color = paste0("#", team_color)) %>%
  deframe()

# team name labels
df_labels <- wnba_team_records %>%
  group_by(team_name) %>%
  filter(game_date == max(game_date)) %>%
  ungroup() 

# visualize records
ggplot(wnba_team_records, aes(x = game_date, y = cumulative_wins, 
  group = team_name, color = team_color)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +
  scale_color_identity() + 
  geom_text_repel(data = df_labels, aes(label = team_name),
    nudge_x = 3, hjust = 0, direction = "y", segment.color = NA, 
    size = 3.5, fontface = "bold") +
  theme_classic() +
  expand_limits(x = max(wnba_team_records$game_date) + 12) +
  theme(legend.position = "none") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2025-09-11"), 
    linetype = "dashed", color = "darkgrey") +
  labs(x = "", y = "cumulative wins", title = "Season Wins by Team") +
  annotate("text", x = as.Date("2025-09-9"), y = 38, 
    label = str_wrap("End of Regular Season", 15), color = "grey40", 
    size = 2.5, hjust = 1)









This plot shows that the Minnesota Lynx had the best record throughout the regular season as they were consistently gapping the rest of the league in wins. Despite their winning record, the Lynx were eliminated in the semi-finals of the playoffs. The Las Vegas Aces struggled in the first half of the season but then went on a massive winning streak which took them to the championships. A few teams, the Connecticut Sun, Chicago Sky, and Dallas Wings, were consistently at the bottom of the standings and did not qualify for the playoffs.


Game Margins
As a way of investigating what factors contribute to the success of dominant teams and downfall of weaker teams, game margins were calculated for various statistics, including field goals, free throws, three pointers, turnovers, and fouls. For example, if a team made two more field goals than their opponent in a game, that would be a margin of +2. If they had one less turnover than their opponent, that would be -1. The averages of these margins across all games were calculated for each team, providing a window into how they typically match up against opponents.


Code
# determine game margins for different performance stats
margins <- wnba_team_records %>%
  group_by(game_id) %>%
  mutate(
    field_margin = field_goals_made - rev(field_goals_made),
    free_margin = free_throws_made - rev(free_throws_made),
    three_margin = three_point_field_goals_made - rev(three_point_field_goals_made),
    turnover_margin = turnovers - rev(turnovers),
    foul_margin = fouls - rev(fouls)) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  select(game_id, team_name, field_margin, free_margin, three_margin, 
    turnover_margin, foul_margin, cumulative_wins) %>%
  arrange(game_id) 

# calculate average margins by team
margin_avgs <- margins %>%
  group_by(team_name) %>%
  summarize(
    avg_field_margin = mean(field_margin),
    avg_free_margin = mean(free_margin),
    avg_three_margin = mean(three_margin),
    avg_turnover_margin = mean(turnover_margin),
    avg_foul_margin = mean(foul_margin),
    cumulative_wins = max(cumulative_wins)
  ) 

# pivot to longer format for plotting
margin_avgs_pivoted <- margin_avgs %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(avg_field_margin, avg_free_margin, avg_three_margin, 
        avg_turnover_margin, avg_foul_margin),
    names_to = "margin_type",
    values_to = "margin_value"
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    margin_type = fct_relevel(margin_type, "avg_field_margin", "avg_free_margin", 
        "avg_three_margin", "avg_turnover_margin", "avg_foul_margin")) %>%
  mutate(
    team_name = fct_reorder(team_name, desc(cumulative_wins)))

# visualize margins by team
ggplot(margin_avgs_pivoted, aes(x = margin_type, y = margin_value, fill = margin_type)) +
  geom_col() +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0) +
  facet_wrap(~team_name, nrow = 2) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_blank(), axis.ticks.x = element_blank()) +
  labs(x = "", y = "") +
  theme(
    axis.text.x = element_blank(), 
    axis.ticks.x = element_blank(), 
    legend.title = element_text(size = 10),
    legend.text = element_text(size = 8),   
    legend.key.size = unit(0.5, "cm")  ) +
  labs(x = "", y = "", fill = "Average Game Margins", 
    title = "Typical Team Performances Against Opponents") +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c("avg_field_margin" = "#3c286e", "avg_free_margin" = "#5091cd", 
      "avg_three_margin" = "#e31837", "avg_turnover_margin" = "#2c5235", 
      "avg_foul_margin" = "#f05023"),
    labels = c("avg_field_margin" = "Field Goals", "avg_free_margin" = "Free Throws",
      "avg_three_margin" = "Three Pointers", "avg_turnover_margin" = "Turnovers", 
      "avg_foul_margin" = "Fouls"))









These bar plots show that the best teams in the league, such as the Lynx, Aces, Dream, and Mercury generally have positive scoring margins and lower or negative turnover and foul margins. The worst teams in the league, such as the Sun, Sky, and Wings display the opposite trends. This suggests that the abilities of a team to outscore and play cleaner basketball than their opponents are strong determinants of their success in the WNBA.


Predicting Season Outcomes
Machine learning algorithms provide another technique for determining factors that contribute to team success. We built a classification model of game outcome (win or loss) using LASSO, an algorithm which shrinks coefficients toward 0. By kicking out predictors, LASSO helps identify the features that are most important to our model.
We trained our LASSO model on all of the regular season games, and tested it on the playoff games.


Code
# remove columns that are unnecessary for predicting game outcomes
wnba_team_lasso <- wnba_team_box %>%
  # filter out all star game
  filter(game_id != 401781604) %>%
  select(-season, -game_date_time, -team_id, -team_uid, -team_slug, -team_location, 
      -team_abbreviation, -team_display_name, -team_short_display_name, -team_color, 
      -team_alternate_color, -team_logo, -team_score, -opponent_team_id, 
      -opponent_team_uid, -opponent_team_slug, -opponent_team_location, 
      -opponent_team_abbreviation, -opponent_team_display_name, 
      -opponent_team_short_display_name, -opponent_team_color, 
      -opponent_team_alternate_color, -opponent_team_logo, -opponent_team_score) %>%
  mutate(
    team_winner = factor(team_winner),
    largest_lead = as.numeric(largest_lead),
    fast_break_points = as.numeric(fast_break_points),
    turnover_points = as.numeric(turnover_points)) %>% 
  mutate(season_day = as.numeric(game_date - as.Date("2025-05-16"))) %>%
  select(-game_date)

# create training dataset with all games before playoffs
lasso_training <- wnba_team_lasso %>%
  filter(season_type != 3) %>%
  select(-game_id, -season_type)

# create test dataset with playoffs
lasso_test <- wnba_team_lasso %>%
  filter(season_type == 3) %>%
  select(-game_id, -season_type)

# model specification
set.seed(212)
model_spec <- logistic_reg() %>%
  set_mode("classification") %>% 
  set_engine("glmnet") %>%
  set_args(mixture = 1, penalty = tune())

# variable recipe
data_rec <- recipe(team_winner ~ . , data = lasso_training) %>%
  step_novel(all_nominal_predictors()) %>%
  step_dummy(all_nominal_predictors())

# workflow (algorithm + recipe)
model_wf <- workflow() %>% 
  add_recipe(data_rec) %>%
  add_model(model_spec) 

# estimate 50 LASSO models
multiple_models <- model_wf %>%
 tune_grid(
    grid = grid_regular(
      penalty(range = c(-5, 3)),     
      levels = 50
    ),
    resamples = vfold_cv(lasso_training, v = 10),
    metrics = metric_set(accuracy)
 )

# determine parsimonious parameter
parsimonious_param <- multiple_models %>%   
  select_by_one_std_err(metric = "accuracy", desc(penalty))

# determine best (highest accuracy) parameter
best_param <- multiple_models %>%   
  select_best(metric = "accuracy")

# build final parsimonious model
final_model <- model_wf %>% 
  finalize_workflow(parsimonious_param) %>% 
  fit(data = lasso_training)

# print coefficients
final_model %>%
  tidy() %>%
  filter(estimate != 0)

# get training accuracy
multiple_models %>% 
  collect_metrics() %>%
  filter(penalty == parsimonious_param$penalty)


The predictors included in our final model and their coefficients can be seen in the equation below.





Fouls and turnovers both had negative coefficients, meaning they decrease the odds of a team winning, which supports our insights from the previous visualization.
Our final model had a lambda value of 0.027 and a cross-validated accuracy of 0.87. This means that our model correctly predicts the game outcome for 86.61% of new games.


Code
# use model to predict playoff game outcomes
test_classifications <- final_model %>% 
  augment(new_data = lasso_test) 

# create confustion matrix
test_confusion <- final_model %>%
  augment(new_data = lasso_test) %>%
  conf_mat(truth = team_winner, estimate = .pred_class)

# print metrics
# summary(test_confusion, event_level = "second")

# represent confusion matrix as mosaic plot
test_confusion %>% 
  autoplot() +
  aes(fill = rep(colnames(test_confusion$table), ncol(test_confusion$table))) + 
  theme(legend.position = "none") +
  labs(title = "Confusion Matrix for Playoff Win Predictions") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#3c286e","#f05023")) 









Our model correctly predicted the outcomes of the playoff games 79.17% of the time. As seen in the confusion matrix above, the model correctly predicted wins (true) and losses (false) in similar proportions. Almost all of the outcomes incorrectly predicted by the model were games in which a team with a massive lead ended up losing. For example, in the second game of the Lynx-Mercury semi-finals series, the Lynx were up by 20 at one point, but ended up losing. The model incorrectly predicted that the Lynx won this game. This demonstrates that although the variables outlined above are generally strong predictors of team success, upsets can happen.



Individual Performance
Season outcomes and team performance stem from the performance of individual players. In the next component of our analysis, we developed and validated a metric for determining the best players in the league.

Player Impact Estimate
Player Impact Estimate (PIE) is a performance metric developed by the NBA to evaluate a player’s contribution to their team’s success in a specific basketball game. It includes both offensive and defensive metrics and balance positive impacts against negative impacts. 10 is considered to be a solid PIE score. The equation used to calculate PIE can be seen below.





We calculated PIE for each player in every game and then calculated the season average for each player. The players with the 10 highest season average PIE scores are listed below.


Code
# calculate game totals for PIE metric calculation
game_totals <- wnba_team_box %>%
  # filter out all star game
  filter(game_id != 401781604)%>%
  group_by(game_id) %>%
  summarize(
    total_points = sum(team_score),
    total_field_goals_made = sum(field_goals_made),
    total_free_throws_made = sum(free_throws_made),
    total_field_goals_attempted = sum(field_goals_attempted),
    total_free_throws_attempted = sum(free_throws_attempted),
    total_defensive_rebounds = sum(defensive_rebounds),
    total_offensive_rebounds = sum(offensive_rebounds),
    total_assists = sum(assists),
    total_steals = sum(steals),
    total_blocks = sum(blocks),
    total_fouls = sum(fouls),
    total_turnovers = sum(turnovers)
  ) %>%
  ungroup()

# calculate PIE for each player in every game
player_game_totals <- wnba_player_box %>%
  full_join(game_totals, by = "game_id") %>%
  select("game_id", "game_date", "athlete_id", "athlete_display_name", "team_id", 
      "team_name", "points", "field_goals_made", "free_throws_made", 
      "field_goals_attempted", "free_throws_attempted", "defensive_rebounds",
      "offensive_rebounds", "assists", "steals", "blocks", "fouls", "turnovers",
      "total_points", "total_field_goals_made", "total_free_throws_made",
      "total_field_goals_attempted", "total_free_throws_attempted",
      "total_defensive_rebounds", "total_offensive_rebounds", "total_assists",
      "total_steals", "total_blocks", "total_fouls", "total_turnovers") %>%
  group_by(game_id, game_date, athlete_id, athlete_display_name, team_id, team_name) %>%
  summarize(player_PIE = ((points + field_goals_made + free_throws_made -
      field_goals_attempted - free_throws_attempted + defensive_rebounds +
      (offensive_rebounds/2) + assists + steals + (blocks/2) - fouls - turnovers) /
      (total_points + total_field_goals_made + total_free_throws_made -
      total_field_goals_attempted - total_free_throws_attempted + 
      total_defensive_rebounds + (total_offensive_rebounds/2) + total_assists + 
      total_steals + (total_blocks/2) - total_fouls - total_turnovers)) * 100) 

# create dataset of season avg PIE scores for each player
PIE <- player_game_totals %>%
  group_by(athlete_display_name, team_name) %>%
  summarize(avg_PIE = mean(player_PIE, na.rm = TRUE)) 

# determine players with 10 highest season avg PIE scores
top10_pie <- PIE %>%
  arrange(desc(avg_PIE)) %>%
  head(10) 

top10_pie %>%
  kable(
    col.names = c("Player", "Team", "PIE"),
    align = "lll"
  ) %>%
  kable_styling()

11.44762


Jackie Young
Aces
11.29745







Principle Component Analysis
As an alternative method of assessing player performance, we used principle component analysis (PCA), a machine learning technique for reducing the dimensionality of data. It turns a set of correlated features into a smaller set of uncorrelated features, called principal components (PCs), which preserve the majority of information in the data. This is useful for analysis as we have many in-game stats that could be used to determine player performance.


Code
# prepare player dataset for PCA
PCA_player <- wnba_player_box %>%
  filter(game_id != 401781604) %>%
  group_by(athlete_display_name, team_name) %>%
  mutate(player_unique = paste0(athlete_display_name, " (", team_name, ")")) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(player_unique, team_name) %>%
  summarize(
      athlete_display_name = first(athlete_display_name),
      avg_minutes = mean(minutes, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_field_goals_made = mean(field_goals_made, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_field_goals_attempted = mean(field_goals_attempted, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_threes_made = mean(three_point_field_goals_made, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_threes_attempted = mean(three_point_field_goals_attempted, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_free_throws_made = mean(free_throws_made, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_free_throws_attempted = mean(free_throws_attempted, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_free_throws_attempted = mean(free_throws_attempted, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_ppg = mean(points, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_blocks = mean(blocks, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_rebounds = mean(rebounds, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_offensive_rebounds = mean(offensive_rebounds, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_defensive_rebounds = mean(offensive_rebounds, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_assists = mean(assists, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_steals = mean(steals, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_turnovers = mean(turnovers, na.rm = TRUE),
      avg_fouls = mean(fouls, na.rm = TRUE),
      games_started = sum(starter, na.rm = TRUE),
      games_ejected = sum(ejected, na.rm = TRUE), 
      games_did_not_play = sum(did_not_play, na.rm = TRUE),
      mean_plus_minus = mean(as.numeric(plus_minus), na.rm = TRUE),
      position = names(which.max(table(athlete_position_name, useNA = "no"))),
      wins = sum(team_winner),
      avg_team_score = mean(team_score)) %>%
  left_join(salary_df, by = join_by(
      athlete_display_name == name, team_name == team_name)) %>%
  left_join(PIE, by = join_by(
      athlete_display_name == athlete_display_name, team_name == team_name)) %>% 
  mutate(across(where(is.numeric), ~ ifelse(is.nan(.), NA, .))) %>%
  drop_na()

# remove duplicate players
PCA_player <- PCA_player[-c(5, 7, 9, 10, 15, 21, 30, 41, 47, 49, 72, 76, 78, 79, 98, 99, 116, 117, 138, 165, 189), ] 

# create unique names for athletes as some athletes played on multiple teams
PCA_player <- PCA_player %>%
  select(-athlete_display_name) %>%
  column_to_rownames("player_unique")

# create dummy variables for categorical features
PCA_player_dummy <- data.frame(model.matrix(~ . - 1, PCA_player))

# remove variables with zero variance
PCA_player_dummy <- PCA_player_dummy %>%
  select(-contractBuyout, -games_ejected)

# standardize features and perform pca
pca_results <- prcomp(PCA_player_dummy, scale = TRUE, center = TRUE)

melt(pca_results$rotation) %>%
  filter(Var2 == "PC1") %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = Var1, y = value)) +
    geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
    labs(y = "Loadings", x = "Original Features", title = "Contributions of Orignal Features to PC1") +
    theme_minimal() +
    theme(legend.position = "none", axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1)) 









The first PC captures the most variability in the data. As seen in this bar chart, the original features that contributed the most to PC1 are in-game statistics, such as shooting percentages and rebounds. This suggests that PC1 is mainly a summary of player performance.


Code
# plot PC1 scores (x-axis) vs PC2 scores (y-axis) of all data points and color by PIE
p <- fviz_pca_ind(
  pca_results, 
  repel = TRUE, 
  label = "none",
  col.ind = PCA_player$avg_PIE, 
  gradient.cols = c("lightyellow", "red"),
  legend.title = "Average PIE",
  title = "PCA Score Plot by PIE"
)

pca_df <- p$data

# Add player names to hover text (assuming column is 'player')
pca_df$player <- row.names(PCA_player)

# Rebuild plot with 'text' aesthetic
p2 <- ggplot(pca_df, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = Col., text = player)) +
  scale_color_gradient(low = "lightyellow", high = "red") +
  labs(title = "PCA Score Plot by PIE", color = "Average PIE", x = "Dim1 (23.2%)", y = "Dim2 (7.1%)") +
  theme_minimal()

# Convert to interactive plotly with hover
ggplotly(p2, tooltip = "text")






PC1 (x-axis) is well aligned with PIE and players with high PC1 scores also tend to have high PIE scores. This validates our use of PIE as a robust and holistic measure of player performance.



Performance and Success
In the final portion of our analysis, we investigated how a player’s performance relates to other measures of success such as salary and recognition.

Salary and Performance
The players with the 10 highest salaries can be seen in the table below.


Code
# determine players with top 10 highest salaries
top10_salary <- salary_df %>%
  arrange(desc(salary)) %>%
  select(name, team_name, salary, contract) %>%
  head(10) 

top10_salary %>%
  kable(
    col.names = c("Player", "Team", "Salary", "Contract"),
    align = "lll"
  ) %>%

Interestingly, Breanna Stewart and Alyssa Thomas are the only two players in this table who also appeared in the PIE Top Ten.
Visualizing the relationship between PIE and salary by contract type provides more nuanced insights.


Code
# join salary and player performance datasets
player_salary_stats <- wnba_player_box %>%
  filter(game_id != 401781604) %>%
  group_by(athlete_display_name, team_name) %>%
  left_join(salary_df, by = join_by(
      athlete_display_name == name, team_name == team_name)) %>%
  select(athlete_display_name, team_name, salary, contract) %>%
  left_join(PIE, by = join_by(
      athlete_display_name == athlete_display_name, team_name == team_name)) %>%
  drop_na() %>%
  mutate(salary_thousands = salary/1000) %>%
  mutate(player_unique = paste0(athlete_display_name, " (", team_name, ")"))

p <- ggplot(player_salary_stats, aes(x = avg_PIE, y = salary_thousands, color = contract, 
  text = player_unique)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(aes(group = contract, color = contract), method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  theme_classic() +
  labs(x = "Player Impact Estimate (Season Average)", y = "Salary in Thousands of Dollars", 
      color = "Contract Type", title = "Player Salaries by Performance and Contract Type") +
  scale_color_manual(
      values = c("Hardship Contract" = "#3c286e", "Unprotected" = "#5091cd", 
          "Waived" =  "#2c5235", "Protected Veteran" = "#e31837", 
          "Protected Rookie Scale" = "#f05023", "7-Day Contract" = "#86cebc"),
      labels = c("Hardship Contract", "Unprotected", "Waived", "Protected Veteran", 
          "Protected Rookie Scale", "7-Day Contract"))

ggplotly(p, tooltip = "text")






The relationship between player performance and salary appears to be strongest for protected veterans, experienced players with guaranteed salaries. The trends for unprotected and waived players also appear to be positive, but this may be due to the several high outliers. The flat slope for protected rookies makes sense given that their salaries are generally standardized. Players with 7-day or hardship contracts typically are only on the roster for a portion of the season, so their salaries also tend to be static.


Popularity and Performance
As a measure of player popularity and recognition, we looked into the Instagram following of a subset of players. The most followed players on Instagram can be seen in the table below.


Code
# players with top 10 highest PIEs
player_game_totals_social <- player_game_totals %>%
  group_by(athlete_display_name, team_name) %>%
  summarize(avg_PIE = mean(player_PIE, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  na.omit()
  
player_game_totals_social_top <- player_game_totals_social %>% 
  ungroup() %>%
  arrange(desc(avg_PIE)) %>%
  slice(1:10)

# players with top 10 highest follower counts
most_followers %>%
  select(athlete_display_name, followers_millions) %>%
  kable(col.names = c("Player", "Followers in Millions"),
        align = "ll") %>%
  kable_styling()

Three of these players also appeared in the top ten PIE table. As a way of visualizing the relationship between player performance and social media following, the players with the 10 highest PIE scores and 10 highest Instagram followers were plotted with respect to their PIE and Instagram follower percentiles. A hype score was determined by calculating the difference between the two percentiles. Players in red are more popular relative to their performance while players in blue are less popular relative to their performance.


Code
# join PIE and follower datasets
top_followers_stats <- most_followers %>%
  left_join(player_game_totals_social, by = "athlete_display_name") %>%
  select(athlete_display_name, team_name, avg_PIE, follower_count)

missing_PIE <- player_game_totals_social_top %>%
  filter(!athlete_display_name %in% top_followers_stats$athlete_display_name)

# manual follower counts
manual_followers <- tibble(
  athlete_display_name = missing_PIE$athlete_display_name,
  follower_count = c(91600, 340000, 494000, 212000, 383000, 183000, 196000)
)

missing_PIE <- missing_PIE %>%
  left_join(manual_followers, by = "athlete_display_name")

final_dataset <- bind_rows(top_followers_stats, missing_PIE) %>%
  distinct(athlete_display_name, .keep_all = TRUE) %>%
  arrange(desc(avg_PIE)) 

final_dataset <- final_dataset %>%
  mutate(follower_pct = percent_rank(follower_count)) %>%
  mutate(PIE_pct = percent_rank(avg_PIE)) %>%
  mutate(hype_score = follower_pct - PIE_pct)

ggplot(final_dataset, aes(x = follower_pct, y = PIE_pct, color = hype_score)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0.5, linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 0.5, linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_text_repel(aes(label = athlete_display_name), size = 3) +
  scale_color_gradient2(low = "#4575b4", mid = "grey", high = "#d73027",
    midpoint = 0, name = "Hype Score") +
  labs(
    title = str_wrap("Popularity vs. Performance: Identifying Over-Hyped and Under-Recognized Players", 70),
    x = "Instagram Popularity (Percentile)",
    y = "On-Court Impact (PIE Percentile)",
    color = "Hype Score") + 
  theme_minimal()









Several of the players in the bottom right quadrant of the plot with positive hype scores, including Paige Bueckers, Angel Reese, Caitlin Clark, Cameron Brink, and Hailey Van Lith are young players who have played in the WNBA for two or less years. These athletes were also some of the most popular college players. Apart from Aliyah Boston, the players with negative hype scores are all veterans who have been in the league since before it began to grow in popularity. This suggests that where a player’s college career falls on the timeline of women’s basketball’s growth has a greater bearing on their recognition and popularity than their performance in the league.

title: Analysis of the 2025 WNBA Season
text:
Conclusions
Our exploration of team performance, individual performance, and player earnings and recognition has provided valuable insights into the factors that contributed to the the success of teams and players during the 2025 WNBA season. We found that the abilities of a team to outscore and play cleaner basketball than their opponents are strong determinants of their success. Game outcomes can be predicted with reasonable accuracy based on a combination of positive metrics that increase the likelihood of winning such as shots made, rebounds, blocks, as well as negative metric including turnovers and fouls. The most successful teams also had some of the overall league’s most impactful players, which can be determined using the comprehensive Player Impact Estimate (PIE) metric. We found that the relationship between player performance and earnings and recognition is complicated. Typically, only players who have been in the league for many years experience salary increases with stronger performance. However, these veteran players may actually be making less overall than their younger, less experienced counterparts. Individual brand deals are becoming increasingly more lucrative. Because popularity is a primary factor in securing brand deals, many of the league’s younger players who have developed under the growing spotlight on women’s basketball and benefited from Name, Image, and Likeness (NIL) deals in college, are having better success tracking down endorsements in the WNBA. This discrepancy in earnings underscores the importance of player demands for a larger share of league revenues and more equitable compensation.






Minnesota Lynx player, Napheesa Collier, has been a key voice in league negotiations for more equitable compensation (reddit).
crumbs: 1  Performance Analysis of the 2025 WNBA Season

title: Analysis of the 2025 WNBA Season
text:
Limitations and Future Work
The Wehoops datasets were clean, and they had ample information that captured the complexity of explaining basketball performance. One limitation is that we were only given data for the 2025 season making it difficult to draw general conclusions about what success in basketball really means for teams and across players’ careers. Another limitation is that salary alone does not capture how much a player makes from their career, as brand deals are a common way that players create income. These means of income are often correlated with a player’s popularity. Measuring popularity is also a difficult process on its own. In our report, we do this using the number of Instagram followers a player has, however, this poses another limitation as followers are not the only thing that represents popularity.
In the future, it would be ideal to look at and compare multiple seasons. It also would be interesting to look at what different players’ and teams’ general playing styles are, and how that can impact their success. Factors such as the speed at which a team plays, how often they rotate players in and out, what sort of plays they run, and other factors that are not as easily quantified.
Also, we found that there are many aspects other than performance that can affect popularity and salary, such as the type of contract and overall changes of popularity of the sport at different points in each player’s career. Additionally, the player performance vs. popularity percentile plot revealed some interesting grouping. Most of the players in the bottom right quadrant, who we concluded are receiving more recognition than is “deserved” based on PIE alone, are younger and white. On the other hand, the players in the top left quadrant, who we identified as under-rated based on PIE and followers, are mostly older and black. This drove us to consider a question that went beyond the scope of our current project, but nonetheless is very interesting: Are there any confounding social factors, such as race, conventional beauty standards, controversy, political opinions, and sexuality, that impact popularity and pay? Overall, while our report is a comprehensive review of the 2025 season, measuring performance and success in many aspects, there is so much more to explore with this topic.

title: Cate S.
text:
Code
library(wehoop)
library(tidyverse)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggrepel)

wnba_pbp <- wehoop::load_wnba_pbp()
wnba_team_box <- wehoop::load_wnba_team_box()
wnba_player_box <- wehoop::load_wnba_player_box()



Player Dataset
dimensions:


Code
# get dimensions
dim(wnba_player_box)


[1] 7140   57


First, I looked at the league’s best players. I made a new dataset with the average stats for each player and ordered it by the most points per game.


Code
# find the league's best players
top_players <- wnba_player_box %>%
  group_by(athlete_display_name) %>%
  summarize(
    avg_ppg = mean(points, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_blocks = mean(blocks, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_rebounds = mean((offensive_rebounds + defensive_rebounds), na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_assists = mean(assists, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_steals = mean(steals, na.rm = TRUE),
    )

top_players %>%
  arrange(desc(avg_ppg)) %>%
  head(10)


# A tibble: 10 × 6
   athlete_display_name avg_ppg avg_blocks avg_rebounds avg_assists avg_steals

A’ja Wilson led the league in scoring. In addition to playing for the championship team, the Las Vegas Aces, she was also named MVP.


Team Dataset
dimensions:


Code
# get dimensions
dim(wnba_team_box)


[1] 624  57


I made running counts of each teams wins and losses so that their records could be determined at any point in the season. I made a visualization showing the cumulative wins for each team over the course of the season.


Code
# determine records for each team
wnba_team_records <- wnba_team_box %>%
  filter(game_id != 401781604) %>%
  mutate(
    win = ifelse(team_winner == TRUE, 1, 0),
    loss = ifelse(team_winner == FALSE, 1, 0)
  ) %>%
  group_by(team_name) %>%
  arrange(team_name, game_date) %>% 
  mutate(
    cumulative_wins = cumsum(win),
    cumulative_losses = cumsum(loss),
    record = paste0(cumulative_wins, "-", cumulative_losses),
    win_pct = cumulative_wins/(cumulative_wins + cumulative_losses)
  ) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate(team_color = paste0("#", team_color))




Code
# visualize records
ggplot(wnba_team_records, aes(x = game_date, y = cumulative_wins, color = team_name)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = as.Date("2025-09-11"), linetype = "dashed") +
  theme_classic()









The black line represents the end of the regular season and beginning of the playoffs. The lines for each team end at varying points, depending on when they were eliminated. The Minnesota Lynx had the best record throughout the regular season, but then they were eliminated in the semi-finals. The Aces struggled in the first half of the season but then went on a massive winning streak which took them to the championships.
Next, I found the teams that led the league in various shot percentages.


Code
# determine teams with the best avg shot percentages
shot_percentages <- wnba_team_records %>%
  select(field_goal_pct, free_throw_pct, three_point_field_goal_pct, team_name) %>%
  group_by(team_name) %>%
  summarise(
    avg_field_goal = mean(field_goal_pct),
    avg_free_throw = mean(free_throw_pct),
    avg_three = mean(three_point_field_goal_pct),
  )

shot_percentages %>%
  select(team_name, avg_field_goal) %>%
  arrange(desc(avg_field_goal)) %>%
  slice(1)

  team_name avg_field_goal

  <chr>              <dbl>
1 Liberty             82.5


Code
shot_percentages %>%
  select(team_name, avg_three) %>%
  arrange(desc(avg_three)) %>%
  slice(1)


# A tibble: 1 × 2
  team_name avg_three
  <chr>         <dbl>
1 Lynx           36.7


These shooting stats support the finding from the previous plot that the Lynx had the best regular season record.
As a way of comparing how each team typically matched up against their opponents, I calculated the margins for various stats. I then took the averages and displayed the teams with the highest field goal, free throw, and three pointer margins and lowest turnover and foul margins.


Code
# determine game margins for different performance stats
margins <- wnba_team_records %>%
  group_by(game_id) %>%
  mutate(
    field_margin = field_goals_made - rev(field_goals_made),
    free_margin = free_throws_made - rev(free_throws_made),
    three_margin = three_point_field_goals_made - rev(three_point_field_goals_made),
    turnover_margin = turnovers - rev(turnovers),
    foul_margin = fouls - rev(fouls)
  ) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  select(game_id, team_name, field_margin, free_margin, three_margin, turnover_margin, foul_margin, cumulative_wins) %>%
  arrange(game_id) 

# calculate average margins by team
margin_avgs <- margins %>%
  group_by(team_name) %>%
  summarize(
    avg_field_margin = mean(field_margin),
    avg_free_margin = mean(free_margin),
    avg_three_margin = mean(three_margin),
    avg_turnover_margin = mean(turnover_margin),
    avg_foul_margin = mean(foul_margin),
    cumulative_wins = max(cumulative_wins)
  ) 

margin_avgs_pivoted <- margin_avgs %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(avg_field_margin, avg_free_margin, avg_three_margin, avg_turnover_margin, avg_foul_margin),
    names_to = "margin_type",
    values_to = "margin_value"
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    margin_type = fct_relevel(margin_type, "avg_field_margin", "avg_free_margin", "avg_three_margin", "avg_turnover_margin", "avg_foul_margin")
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    team_name = fct_reorder(team_name, desc(cumulative_wins))
  )

margin_avgs %>%
  select(team_name, avg_field_margin) %>%
  arrange(desc(avg_field_margin)) %>%
  slice(1)


# A tibble: 1 × 2
  team_name avg_field_margin
  <chr>                <dbl>

  select(team_name, avg_free_margin) %>%
  arrange(desc(avg_free_margin)) %>%

It is interesting to see a variety of teams represented in these stats. It make sense that the Lynx had the greatest field goal margin given that they had the best record.
These faceted bar plots display the average game margins of these stats for each team.


Code
# visualize margins by team
ggplot(margin_avgs_pivoted, aes(x = margin_type, y = margin_value, fill = margin_type)) +
  geom_col() +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0) +
  facet_wrap(~team_name) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_blank(), axis.ticks.x = element_blank()) +
  labs(x = "", y = "")









The best teams in the league, such as the Lynx, Aces, Dream, and Mercury generally have positive scoring margins and lower or negative turnover and foul margins. The worst teams in the league, such as the Sun, Sky, and Wings display the opposite trends.


Play-By-Play Dataset


Code
# get dimensions
dim(wnba_pbp)


[1] 121342     62


For the play-by-play dataset, I made a variable for the type of shot.


Code
# create shot type variable
wnba_pbp <- wnba_pbp %>%
  filter(shooting_play) %>%
  mutate(shot_type = case_when(
    str_detect(type_text, "Jump Shot") ~ "Jump Shot",
    str_detect(type_text, "Layup Shot") | str_detect(type_text, "Layup") ~ "Layup Shot",
    str_detect(type_text, "Free Throw") ~ "Free Throw",
    str_detect(type_text, "Hook Shot") | str_detect(type_text, "Hook") ~ "Hook Shot",
    str_detect(type_text, "Tip Shot") ~ "Tip Shot",
    str_detect(type_text, "Dunk") ~ "Dunk Shot"
  )) 


This barplot displays the frequencies of different shot types, differentiated by whether or not the shot was made.


Code
wnba_pbp %>%  
  filter(game_id != 401781604) %>% #filter out All Star game
  ggplot(aes(y = shot_type, fill = scoring_play)) +
  geom_bar() +
  theme_classic() +
  labs(x = "count", y = "shot type", fill = "scoring play")









Jumpshots are by far the most common shot, but they are not the easiest to make. Free throws and layups, which make up the majority of the rest of shots, are easier to make.

title: Karyna S.
section: Using coordinates to map players’ shot completion
text:
Using coordinates to map players’ shot completion


Code
#Top three WNBA players in different positions by points
wilson <- 3149391
collier <- 3917450
ionescu <- 4066533

#Dividing by player id and position
df <- wnba %>%
  filter(scoring_play == TRUE) %>%
  filter(athlete_id_1 %in% c(ionescu, wilson, collier)) %>%
  select(athlete_id_1, type_text, coordinate_x_raw, coordinate_y_raw) %>%
  mutate(player = case_when(
    athlete_id_1 == ionescu ~ "Sabrina Ionescu",
    athlete_id_1 == wilson ~ "A'ja Wilson",
    athlete_id_1 == collier ~ "Napheesa Collier")) %>%
  mutate(position = case_when(
    player == "A'ja Wilson" ~ "Center",
    player == "Napheesa Collier" ~ "Forward",
    player == "Sabrina Ionescu" ~ "Guard"
  )) %>%
  mutate(coordinate_y_raw = coordinate_y_raw + 4)

title: Appendix A — Proposal
text: Title: Analysis of the 2025 WNBA Season

title: Appendix A — Proposal
section: Authors: Cate Stacy and Karyna Steele
text: Authors: Cate Stacy and Karyna Steele

title: Appendix A — Proposal
text:
Project Description
We are analyzing Women’s National Basketball Association (WNBA) data from the 2025 season. We have access to play-by-play, team box score, and player box score data. We plan on exploring factors that contribute to the success of teams and individuals.

title: Appendix A — Proposal
text:
Research Questions

What factors, such as points scored, turnovers, or fouls, influence playing time for a WNBA player?
What are the characteristics of winning teams? Do these characteristics align with the outcome of the championships?

title: Appendix A — Proposal
text:
Inspiration
As student-athletes, we were interested in pursuing a project surrounding women’s sports. In recent years, women’s basketball has experienced a rapid rise in popularity. This has coincided with the growth of the WNBA, making it an exciting topic to analyze.

title: Appendix A — Proposal
text:
Data


Code
library(wehoop)
library(tidyverse)

wnba_pbp <- wehoop::load_wnba_pbp()
wnba_team_box <- wehoop::load_wnba_team_box()
wnba_player_box <- wehoop::load_wnba_player_box()

title: Appendix A — Proposal
text:
Implementation Plan

Clean the data sets (together)



Identify NA values and filter variables we need to answer our research questions



EDA (individually) a.Make visualizations and identify variables that could be valuable for our analysis



Summarize finding and narrow down research questions



Research (individually)



Conduct research about the data (ex. How it was collected)
Do background research on topic



Create preliminary findings presentation (together)



Collaborate on presentation and present to classmates



Create data story and present to class (together)



Ensure that report is clean (hide warnings, ensure there are no long outputs)
Revise according to feedback



Clean up and organize GitHub repository (together)



Add README file



Create presentation slides and video (together)
Evaluation and reflection (individually)

title: Appendix B — Case Study
text:
We read a data story called “Text analysis of Trump’s tweets confirms he writes only the (angrier) Android half.” David Robinson looked at a dataset of Trump’s tweets, sent from iPhone and Android. In his analysis, he looked at time of day, hashtag and link usage, retweets, word composition, and sentiment. He concluded that the Android and iPhone tweets are from different people and that the Android tweets (written by Trump) are angrier than the iPhone tweets (written by his campaign). Overall, we thought the report had a nice flow between text, visualizations, and code chunks and is a good model for our project. Listed below are some more detailed observations about the structure of the report.

Presents the driving question/purpose of analysis early on in the data story
Begins with a brief overview describing the approach taken and main findings before diving into the full details
Describes the data

Clean, small code chunks interspersed with text to help guide the reader
Simple clean visualizations effectively display trends in the data

Rather than being lumped into a single section, the results and analysis are broken up into specific sections of the investigation
Wraps up analysis in conclusion and explores meaning of findings
Not very technical, avoids jargon, understandable by wide audience
Visualizations are simple and have clear messages, but the report could have benefited from at least one more complex, eye-catching visualization

Citation: Robinson, D. (2016, August 9). Text analysis of Trump’s tweets confirms he writes only the (angrier) Android half. Variance Explained. http://varianceexplained.org/r/trump-tweets/

game_totals <- wnba_team_box %>%
  filter(game_id != 401781604)%>%
  group_by(game_id) %>%
  summarize(
    total_points = sum(team_score),
    total_field_goals_made = sum(field_goals_made),
    total_free_throws_made = sum(free_throws_made),
    total_field_goals_attempted = sum(field_goals_attempted),
    total_free_throws_attempted = sum(free_throws_attempted),
    total_defensive_rebounds = sum(defensive_rebounds),
    total_offensive_rebounds = sum(offensive_rebounds),
    total_assists = sum(assists),
    total_steals = sum(steals),
    total_blocks = sum(blocks),
    total_fouls = sum(fouls),
    total_turnovers = sum(turnovers)
  ) %>%
  ungroup()

player_game_totals <- wnba_player_box %>%
  full_join(game_totals, by = "game_id") %>%
  select("game_id", "game_date", "athlete_id", "athlete_display_name", "team_id", "team_name", "points", "field_goals_made", "free_throws_made", "field_goals_attempted", "free_throws_attempted", "defensive_rebounds", "offensive_rebounds", "assists", "steals", "blocks", "fouls", "turnovers", "total_points", "total_field_goals_made", "total_free_throws_made", "total_field_goals_attempted", "total_free_throws_attempted", "total_defensive_rebounds", "total_offensive_rebounds", "total_assists", "total_steals", "total_blocks", "total_fouls", "total_turnovers") %>%
  group_by(game_id, game_date, athlete_id, athlete_display_name, team_id, team_name) %>%
  summarize(player_PIE = ((points + field_goals_made + free_throws_made - field_goals_attempted - free_throws_attempted + defensive_rebounds + (offensive_rebounds/2) + assists + steals + (blocks/2) - fouls - turnovers) / (total_points + total_field_goals_made + total_free_throws_made - total_field_goals_attempted - total_free_throws_attempted + total_defensive_rebounds + (total_offensive_rebounds/2) + total_assists + total_steals + (total_blocks/2) - total_fouls - total_turnovers)) * 100) 

top10_pie <- player_game_totals %>%
  group_by(athlete_display_name, team_name) %>%
  summarize(avg_PIE = mean(player_PIE, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  arrange(desc(avg_PIE)) %>%
  head(10)

# determine records for each team
wnba_team_records <- wnba_team_box %>%
  filter(team_name != "TEAM CLARK", team_name != "TEAM COLLIER") %>% # remove All Star teams
  mutate(
    win = ifelse(team_winner == TRUE, 1, 0),
    loss = ifelse(team_winner == FALSE, 1, 0)
  ) %>%
  group_by(team_name) %>%
  arrange(team_name, game_date) %>% 
  mutate(
    cumulative_wins = cumsum(win),
    cumulative_losses = cumsum(loss),
    record = paste0(cumulative_wins, "-", cumulative_losses),
    win_pct = cumulative_wins/(cumulative_wins + cumulative_losses)
  ) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate(team_color = paste0("#", team_color))

Code
# determine game margins for different performance stats
margins <- wnba_team_records %>%
  group_by(game_id) %>%
  mutate(
    field_margin = field_goals_made - rev(field_goals_made),
    free_margin = free_throws_made - rev(free_throws_made),
    three_margin = three_point_field_goals_made - rev(three_point_field_goals_made),
    turnover_margin = turnovers - rev(turnovers),
    foul_margin = fouls - rev(fouls)
  ) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  select(game_id, team_name, field_margin, free_margin, three_margin, turnover_margin, foul_margin, cumulative_wins) %>%
  arrange(game_id) 

# calculate average margins by team
margin_avgs <- margins %>%
  group_by(team_name) %>%
  summarize(
    avg_field_margin = mean(field_margin),
    avg_free_margin = mean(free_margin),
    avg_three_margin = mean(three_margin),
    avg_turnover_margin = mean(turnover_margin),
    avg_foul_margin = mean(foul_margin),
    cumulative_wins = max(cumulative_wins)
  ) 

margin_avgs_pivoted <- margin_avgs %>%
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(avg_field_margin, avg_free_margin, avg_three_margin, avg_turnover_margin, avg_foul_margin),
    names_to = "margin_type",
    values_to = "margin_value"
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    margin_type = fct_relevel(margin_type, "avg_field_margin", "avg_free_margin", "avg_three_margin", "avg_turnover_margin", "avg_foul_margin")
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    team_name = fct_reorder(team_name, desc(cumulative_wins))
  )

full_urls <- str_c(start_url, team_urls, "/")

salary_info <- function(url) {
  Sys.sleep(1)
  webpage <- read_html(url)

  team <- webpage %>%
    html_element("h1.salary_title") %>%
    html_text(trim = TRUE)
  
  rows <- webpage %>%
    html_elements("tbody tr")

  map_df(rows, function(row) {

    player <- row %>%
      html_element("td.salary_player_name a") %>%
      html_text(trim = TRUE)

    salary_cell <- row %>%
      html_elements("td.salary_cap_hit") %>%
      .[1]

    salary <- salary_cell %>%
      html_attr("sorttable_customkey") %>%
      as.numeric()

    contract_type <- salary_cell %>%
      html_attr("title") %>%
      na_if("")

    tibble(
      name = player,
      team = team,
      salary = salary,
      contract = contract_type
    )
  })
}

all_pages <- purrr::map(full_urls, salary_info)
salary_df <- bind_rows(all_pages)

# predicting playoff outcomes using LASSO on team dataset
wnba_team_lasso <- wnba_team_box %>%
  filter(game_id != 401781604) %>%
  select(-season, -game_date_time, -team_id, -team_uid, -team_slug, -team_location, -team_abbreviation, -team_display_name, -team_short_display_name, -team_color, -team_alternate_color, -team_logo, -team_score, -opponent_team_id, -opponent_team_uid, -opponent_team_slug, -opponent_team_location, -opponent_team_abbreviation, -opponent_team_display_name, -opponent_team_short_display_name, -opponent_team_color, -opponent_team_alternate_color, -opponent_team_logo, -opponent_team_score) %>%
  mutate(
    team_winner = factor(team_winner),
    largest_lead = as.numeric(largest_lead),
    fast_break_points = as.numeric(fast_break_points),
    turnover_points = as.numeric(turnover_points)) %>% 
  mutate(season_day = as.numeric(game_date - as.Date("2025-05-16"))) %>%
  select(-game_date)

lasso_training <- wnba_team_lasso %>%
  filter(season_type != 3) %>%
  select(-game_id, -season_type)

lasso_test <- wnba_team_lasso %>%
  filter(season_type == 3) %>%
  select(-game_id, -season_type)

# model specification
set.seed(212)
model_spec <- logistic_reg() %>%
  set_mode("classification") %>% 
  set_engine("glmnet") %>%
  set_args(mixture = 1, penalty = tune())

# variable recipe
data_rec <- recipe(team_winner ~ . , data = lasso_training) %>%
  step_novel(all_nominal_predictors()) %>%
  step_dummy(all_nominal_predictors())

# workflow (algorithm + recipe)
model_wf <- workflow() %>% 
  add_recipe(data_rec) %>%
  add_model(model_spec) 

# estimate 50 LASSO models
multiple_models <- model_wf %>%
 tune_grid(
    grid = grid_regular(
      penalty(range = c(-5, 3)),     
      levels = 50
    ),
    resamples = vfold_cv(lasso_training, v = 10),
    metrics = metric_set(accuracy)
 )

# determine parsimonious parameter
parsimonious_param <- multiple_models %>%   
  select_by_one_std_err(metric = "accuracy", desc(penalty))

# determine best (highest accuracy) parameter
best_param <- multiple_models %>%   
  select_best(metric = "accuracy")

# build final parsimonious model
final_model <- model_wf %>% 
  finalize_workflow(parsimonious_param) %>% 
  fit(data = lasso_training)

# print coefficients
final_model %>%
  tidy() %>%
  filter(estimate != 0)

# predicting teams in the playoffs using random forest
wnba_team_lasso <- wnba_team_box %>%
  filter(game_id != 401781604) %>%
  select(-season, -game_date_time, -team_id, -team_uid, -team_slug, -team_location, -team_abbreviation, -team_display_name, -team_short_display_name, -team_color, -team_alternate_color, -team_logo, -opponent_team_id, -opponent_team_uid, -opponent_team_slug, -opponent_team_location, -opponent_team_abbreviation, -opponent_team_display_name, -opponent_team_short_display_name, -opponent_team_color, -opponent_team_alternate_color, -opponent_team_logo, -opponent_team_name) %>%
  mutate(
    team_winner = factor(team_winner),
    team_name = factor(team_name),
    largest_lead = as.numeric(largest_lead),
    fast_break_points = as.numeric(fast_break_points),
    turnover_points = as.numeric(turnover_points)) %>% 
  mutate(season_day = as.numeric(game_date - as.Date("2025-05-16"))) %>%
  select(-game_date)

lasso_training <- wnba_team_lasso %>%
  filter(season_type != 3) %>%
  select(-game_id, -season_type)

lasso_test <- wnba_team_lasso %>%
  filter(season_type == 3) %>%
  select(-game_id, -season_type)

# model specification
set.seed(212)
# STEP 1: Model Specification
rf_spec <- rand_forest()  %>%
  set_mode("classification") %>%
  set_engine(engine = "ranger") %>% 
  set_args(
    mtry = NULL,
    trees = 500,
    min_n = 2,
    probability = FALSE, # give classifications, not probability calculations
    importance = "impurity" # use Gini index to measure variable importance
  )

# STEP 2: Build the forest or bagging model
# There are no preprocessing steps or tuning, hence no need for a workflow!
ensemble_model <- rf_spec %>% 
  fit(team_name ~ ., data = lasso_training)


# Put in a data.frame object with x1 and x2 values (at minimum)
ensemble_model %>% 
  predict(new_data = lasso_test)  

# Out-of-bag (OOB) prediction error
ensemble_model

# OOB confusion matrix
ensemble_model %>% 
  extract_fit_engine() %>% 
  pluck("confusion.matrix") %>% 
  t()

ensemble_model %>% 
  predict(new_data = lasso_test) %>% 
  cbind(lasso_test) %>% 
  conf_mat(
    truth = team_name,
    estimate = .pred_class
  )

# PCA on player dataset
PCA_player <- wnba_player_box %>%
  filter(game_id != 401781604) %>%
  group_by(athlete_display_name, team_name) %>%
  mutate(player_unique = paste0(athlete_display_name, "_", team_name)) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(player_unique, team_name) %>%
  summarize(
    athlete_display_name = first(athlete_display_name),
    avg_minutes = mean(minutes, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_field_goals_made = mean(field_goals_made, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_field_goals_attempted = mean(field_goals_attempted, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_threes_made = mean(three_point_field_goals_made, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_threes_attempted = mean(three_point_field_goals_attempted, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_free_throws_made = mean(free_throws_made, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_free_throws_attempted = mean(free_throws_attempted, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_free_throws_attempted = mean(free_throws_attempted, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_ppg = mean(points, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_blocks = mean(blocks, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_rebounds = mean(rebounds, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_offensive_rebounds = mean(offensive_rebounds, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_defensive_rebounds = mean(offensive_rebounds, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_assists = mean(assists, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_steals = mean(steals, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_turnovers = mean(turnovers, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_fouls = mean(fouls, na.rm = TRUE),
    games_started = sum(starter, na.rm = TRUE),
    games_ejected = sum(ejected, na.rm = TRUE), 
    games_did_not_play = sum(did_not_play, na.rm = TRUE),
    mean_plus_minus = mean(as.numeric(plus_minus), na.rm = TRUE),
    position = names(which.max(table(athlete_position_name, useNA = "no"))),
    wins = sum(team_winner),
    avg_team_score = mean(team_score)
    ) %>%
  left_join(salary_df, by = join_by(athlete_display_name == name, team_name == team_name)) %>%
  left_join(PIE, by = join_by(athlete_display_name == athlete_display_name, team_name == team_name)) %>% 
  mutate(across(where(is.numeric), ~ ifelse(is.nan(.), NA, .))) %>%
  drop_na()

library(wehoop)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)




Code
wnba_pbp <- wehoop::load_wnba_pbp()
wnba_team_box <- wehoop::load_wnba_team_box()
wnba_player_box <- wehoop::load_wnba_player_box()

top_players <- wnba_player_box %>%
  filter(game_id != 401781604) %>%
  group_by(athlete_display_name, team_name) %>%
  summarize(
    avg_ppg = mean(points, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_blocks = mean(blocks, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_rebounds = mean((offensive_rebounds + defensive_rebounds), na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_assists = mean(assists, na.rm = TRUE),
    avg_steals = mean(steals, na.rm = TRUE),
    )

game_totals <- wnba_team_box %>%
  filter(game_id != 401781604)%>%
  group_by(game_id) %>%
  summarize(
    total_points = sum(team_score),
    total_field_goals_made = sum(field_goals_made),
    total_free_throws_made = sum(free_throws_made),
    total_field_goals_attempted = sum(field_goals_attempted),
    total_free_throws_attempted = sum(free_throws_attempted),
    total_defensive_rebounds = sum(defensive_rebounds),
    total_offensive_rebounds = sum(offensive_rebounds),
    total_assists = sum(assists),
    total_steals = sum(steals),
    total_blocks = sum(blocks),
    total_fouls = sum(fouls),
    total_turnovers = sum(turnovers)
  ) %>%
  ungroup()

player_game_totals <- wnba_player_box %>%
  full_join(game_totals, by = "game_id") %>%
  select("game_id", "game_date", "athlete_display_name", "team_id", 
         "team_name", "points", "field_goals_made", "free_throws_made", "field_goals_attempted", 
         "free_throws_attempted", "defensive_rebounds", "offensive_rebounds", "assists", 
         "steals", "blocks", "fouls", "turnovers", "total_points", "total_field_goals_made", 
         "total_free_throws_made", "total_field_goals_attempted", "total_free_throws_attempted", 
         "total_defensive_rebounds", "total_offensive_rebounds", "total_assists", 
         "total_steals", "total_blocks", "total_fouls", "total_turnovers") %>%
  group_by(game_id, game_date, athlete_display_name, team_id, team_name) %>%
  summarize(player_PIE = ((points + field_goals_made + free_throws_made - field_goals_attempted - 
                             free_throws_attempted + defensive_rebounds + (offensive_rebounds/2) + 
                             assists + steals + (blocks/2) - fouls - turnovers) / (total_points + total_field_goals_made +
                                                                                     total_free_throws_made -
                                                                                     total_field_goals_attempted -
                                                                                     total_free_throws_attempted +
                                                                                     total_defensive_rebounds +
                                                                                     (total_offensive_rebounds/2) + total_assists +
                                                                                     total_steals + (total_blocks/2) - total_fouls -
                                                                                     total_turnovers)) * 100) 

player_game_totals <- player_game_totals %>%
  group_by(athlete_display_name, team_name) %>%
  summarize(avg_PIE = mean(player_PIE, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  na.omit()

player_game_totals2 <- player_game_totals %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  arrange(desc(avg_PIE)) %>%
  slice(1:10)

library(rvest)
library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)

url <- "https://www.revolt.tv/article/wnba-players-with-the-most-instagram-followers"

page <- read_html(url)

headers <- page %>%
  html_elements("h2 strong") %>%
  html_text2

most_followers <- headers %>%
  str_remove("^\\d+\\.\\s*") %>%
  str_match("^(.*?)\\s*\\((.*)\\)$") %>% 
  as_tibble() %>%
  select(V2, V3) %>%
  mutate(V3 = V3 %>%                  
           str_remove("over\\s*") %>%           
           str_replace(" million", "e6") %>%    
           as.numeric()) %>%
  filter(V2 != "Candace Parker") %>%
  arrange(desc(V3)) %>%
  slice(1:10)

colnames(most_followers) <- c("athlete_display_name", "follower_count")
most_followers %>%
  kable(col.names = c("Player", "Number of Followers"),
        align = "ll") %>%
  kable_styling()

top_followers_stats <- most_followers %>%
  left_join(player_game_totals, by = "athlete_display_name") %>%
  select(athlete_display_name, team_name, avg_PIE, follower_count)

missing_PIE <- player_game_totals2 %>%
  filter(!athlete_display_name %in% top_followers_stats$athlete_display_name)

manual_followers <- tibble(
  athlete_display_name = missing_PIE$athlete_display_name,
  follower_count = c(91600, 340000, 494000, 212000, 383000, 183000, 196000)
)

missing_PIE <- missing_PIE %>%
  left_join(manual_followers, by = "athlete_display_name")

final_dataset <- bind_rows(top_followers_stats, missing_PIE) %>%
  distinct(athlete_display_name, .keep_all = TRUE) %>%
  arrange(desc(avg_PIE)) 

print(final_dataset)

library(ggrepel)

final_dataset <- final_dataset %>%
  mutate(
    follower_pct = percent_rank(follower_count)
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    PIE_pct = percent_rank(avg_PIE)
  ) %>%
  mutate(
    hype_score = follower_pct - PIE_pct
  )

ggplot(final_dataset, aes(x = follower_pct, y = PIE_pct, color = hype_score)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0.5, linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 0.5, linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_text_repel(aes(label = athlete_display_name), size = 3) +
  labs(
    title = "Popularity vs Performance: Identifying Over-Hyped and Under-Recognized Players",
    x = "Instagram Popularity (Percentile)",
    y = "On-Court Impact (PIE Percentile)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()
